etymology.description: 胸(胸) (xiōng, "chest"), 大(大) (dà, "big"), 无(無) (wú, "no"), 脑(腦) (nǎo, "brain")
etymology.interpretation: This expression combines 胸(胸) (xiōng, "chest") and 大(大) (dà, "big") to refer to a prominent physical feature, with 无(無) (wú, "no") and 脑(腦) (nǎo, "brain") implying a lack of intelligence. It is often used disparagingly to describe someone perceived as physically attractive but lacking in intelligence.

examples.chinese: 她常常被人称为胸大无脑(她常常被人稱為胸大無腦)。
examples.pinyin: Tā chángcháng bèi rén chēngwéi xiōng dà wú nǎo.
examples.english: She is often labeled a bimbo.

examples.chinese: 有的明星虽然外表光鲜(有的明星雖然外表光鮮)，但其实她们不过是胸大无脑(但其實她們不過是胸大無腦)。
examples.pinyin: Yǒu de míngxīng suīrán wàibiǎo guāngxían, dàn qíshí tāmen bùguò shì xiōng dà wú nǎo.
examples.english: Some celebrities may appear glamorous on the outside, but in reality, they are just bimbos.
